The purpose of the project is therefore to support government institutions, civil society and the general population to reduce disaster risk within the country and to adapt to the negative effects of climate change, in order to guarantee development gains for the country as a whole, and especially for those most vulnerable. To make contributions to the achievement of the above, the project will concentrate on 4 different thematic areas, in line with the UNDAF outputs, focusing on:1) the development of integrated and operational policy and regulatory framework for effective coordination and implementation of disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation; 2) active participation of local communities in risk reduction activities and natural resources management in districts at risk; 3) integrated information management and monitoring systems for disasters; and 4) ensuring that communities in disaster prone areas benefit effectively from emergency preparedness, humanitarian assistance and early recovery actions.

Due to heavy and persistent rains in the first two weeks of January 2013 in the central and southern parts of the country, there were significant damages to infrastructure in Maputo city and in numerous settlements in Gaza Province (Chibuto, Chokwe, Guija, Xai-Xai and Bilene). The flooding was further exacerbated by the high rainfalls upstream in South Africa, Malawi and Zimbabwe, and sudden increments in outflows from those neighboring countries through the main river basins in the south and central parts of the country, namely: Limpopo, Incomati, Inhanombe and Save in the south and (Zambezi, Pungoe and Buzi in the central regions).  Due to the high magnitude and extend of impact of the floods, a red alert was declared on January 12 preceded by an institutional red alert on January 22, 2013 requesting all ministries and development partners to rollout their emergency funds and to further mobilize resources to address the unmet gaps. 
As part of UNDP's mandate during emergencies, being responsible for early recovery processes which begin from the onset of the disaster and coordination, it was crucial for UNDP to take this leadership role to ensure that all sectoral needs are properly addressed.  
The project document was signed in January 2013 focusing on the following Outcome "Sustainable and effective management of natural resources and disaster risk reduction benefit all people in Mozambique, particularly the most vulnerable"

In response to the devastating floods that hit Mozambique from early 2013, the project aims to support the disaster risk resilient livelihoods recovery of flood-affected communities in Gaza province.  In close partnership with Government at national, provincial and district levels, affected communities and where possible the private sector coordinated by INGC, the project seeks to restore enabling environment for flood-affected communities in Limpopo river basin to recover from the impact of the floods and "build back better" through three interlinked outputs.
1.	Disaster resilient livelihoods and economic opportunities for the flood-affected people in Gaza Province restored and improved:
2.	Capacity of local authorities and communities' livelihoods recovery strengthened:
3.	Coordination of livelihoods recovery by Early Recovery Cluster strengthened.
Capacity Development on Mainstreaming Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Change Adaptation into National and Provincial Plans and Programs in Mozambique
